awd_titl_txt: Encouraging Data Sharing and Reuse in the Field of Collective Behavior through Hackathon-Style Collaborative Workshops
awd_abstract_narration:
The investigators will bring together diverse researchers who work in the field of collective and emergent behavior. Collective and emergent behavior is the study of complex biological and social systems, ranging from bacterial colonies to human groups.  The hackathon-style workshop draws researchers around identifying best practice mechanisms for sharing data, communicating methods of data analysis, and reusing publicly available data.   The investigators propose a series of two workshops where teams of 2-5 participants work on a specific project during the duration of the 3-day event. An objective of the workshop is to foster novel collaborations between researchers in biology, data science, mathematics, computer science and physics, all of whom have an interest in collective behavior.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of this proposal was to run a workshop that brought together researchers from biology, mathematics, computer science, engineering and system sciences. The researchers were at all stages of their career - undergraduates, PhD students, post-docs and faculty. At the workshop, we put together three teams with a blend of biological and mathematical backgrounds. The goal was for groups to work on novel collective behavior problems, and for each person to bring their own unique perspectives, approaches and skills. We had teams that work on varied problems. One team worked on how the California blackworm forms huge entangled masses and coordinates their behavior. Another team worked on how social interaction processes influences the spread of human infection through networks. A third team generated theoretical models to determine how cities can be planned more effectively to improve human quality of life.  All groups made good progress during the meeting. In terms of intellectual merit and broader impacts, the researchers established novel collaborations, made significant advances in their data analysis and model development. The project also provided opportunities for young researchers to take leadership roles and to work closely with more senior researchers. Since the completion of the workshop, groups have continued to work together. The plan is for these projects to reach publication stage within the next year to eighteen months. Once complete, this work will be publicized by the organizers on social media for it to reach a wider audience.


Last Modified: 06/08/2023
Modified by: James Curley
